claim_text: The NeuroReach VR system aims to train stroke patients in reach and grasp movements using an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task. This system will provide visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to enhance selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. The project utilizes a Quest 3S headset with Shared Spatial Anchors to create an immersive and interactive training environment. The intuitiveness of feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment are key features of the system, with potential for clinical application.
summary: The evidence suggests the system is still in development with significant challenges and potential alternatives, indicating it may not be ready for clinical application as claimed.
detail: The evidence snippets highlight several challenges in the development of the NeuroReach VR system, including 'anchor drift,' 'noisy tilt estimation,' and 'inconsistent haptic support' (E2). Furthermore, the proposed solutions involve workarounds like 'relocalizing anchors at session start' and 'low pass tilt and debounce events' (E2), suggesting the core technology is not yet robust. The project also considers alternatives such as 'using fiducials instead of anchors' or 'running tracing without haptics' (E2), which deviate from the claimed multimodal feedback system. The mention of a 'pilot study and analysis' with a small participant group (5-10) (E1) further indicates the system is in an early evaluation phase, not yet proven for clinical application.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

Work Package 2 : VR Task and Multimodal Feedback (Weeks 3–5)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Build Passthrough Pouring task; build MX Ink Tracing task; add neon halos and virtual liquid particles;

claim_text: Work Package 2 focuses on building the Passthrough Pouring task and the MX Ink Tracing task, incorporating visual elements like neon halos and virtual liquid particles. This package also includes the integration of multimodal feedback, such as visual, auditory, and haptic cues. Work Package 3 is dedicated to developing an adaptive controller with hysteresis and implementing logging features with rolling summaries at high frequencies (50 to 90 Hz). The adaptive controller aims to manage feedback fading and adjust task parameters based on user performance.
summary: The claim describes Work Package 2 focusing on specific tasks and multimodal feedback, but the evidence details a demonstration plan that seems to integrate elements from both Work Package 2 and 3, making the distinct focus of WP2 unclear.
detail: The claim states Work Package 2 focuses on Passthrough Pouring and MX Ink Tracing with visual and multimodal feedback. However, the evidence (E1) outlines a demonstration plan that includes 'real time halos, ticks and error bars' (consistent with WP2's visual elements) but also mentions a 'Projected dashboard shows on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error and SPARC updated per trial to observe real-time adaptive difficulty and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation.' This adaptive difficulty and fading feedback, along with muscle activation, are described as features of the adaptive controller in Work Package 3. The evidence does not clearly delineate which features belong to WP2 and which to WP3, or how they are integrated within the demonstration.

Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows

and fading feedback based on the user’s muscle activation. (iii) An offline video presentation showcasing the full
demonstration loop and summarized pilot metrics.
IV. *OPTIONAL MYO ARMBAND EXTENSION
Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.
REFERENCES
[1] Margit Alt Murphy, Carin Will´en, and Katharina Stibrant Sunnerhagen. Movement kinematics during a drinking task are associated with
the activity capacity level after stroke. Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 26(9):1106–1115, 2012.
[2] Daniel Berger and Andrea d’Avella. Myoelectric control and virtual reality to enhance motor rehabilitation after stroke. Frontiers in
Bioengineering and Biotechnology, 12:1376000, 2024.
[3] H. Huang, S. L. Wolf, and J. He. Recent developments in biofeedback for neuromotor rehabilitation. Journal of NeuroEngineering and
Rehabilitation, 3(11), 2006.
[4] H. P. Lin et al. A usability study on mobile emg-guided wrist extension training in subacute stroke patients (myoguide). Journal of
NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation, 21:39, 2024.
[5] Maike Maier, Bel´en R. Ballester, and Paul F. M. J. Verschure. Principles of neurorehabilitation after stroke based on motor learning and
brain plasticity mechanisms. Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience, 13:74, 2019.
[6] Styrmir Saevarsson, Vala Gudmundsdottir, and Arni Kristjansson. Kinematic analysis of spiral drawing and clock drawing as measures
of upper limb function after stroke. Neuropsychological Rehabilitation, 25(5):744–763, 2015.

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.
